Whitney received over 600 awards throughout her career. In 2006 she was named the most awarded female artist of all time by Guinness World Records. == 1985 == {| class="wikitable" ! width=25% | Awards show ! width=25% | Nomination(s) ! width=45% | Categories ! width=5% | Result(s) |- | The 18th NAACP Image Awards | style="text-align:center"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Outstanding New Artist | |- |rowspan="2"|1985 Billboard Number One Awards[A] |style="text- align:center" rowspan="2"|Whitney Houston (herself) | New Pop Artist | |- | New Black Artist | |} Note: *A^ The Billboard Music Awards, based on Billboard magazine's year-end charts, was not held before 1990. They were present and called to top list getters as Billboard Number One Awards before that time == 1986 == {| class="wikitable" ! width=25% | Awards show ! width=25% | Nomination(s) ! width=45% | Categories ! width=5% | Result(s) |- | rowspan="6" | The 13th American Music Awards | style="text-align:center" rowspan="2" | Whitney Houston (herself) | Favorite Pop/Rock Female Artist | |- | Favorite Soul/R&B; Houston received the award for her album, Whitney, the first album by a female singer to debut at No. 1 on the popular music charts, featuring the hit single, "I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)." == 1988 == {| class="wikitable" ! width=25% | Awards show or organization ! width=25% | Nomination(s) ! width=45% | Categories ! width=5% | Result(s) |- | rowspan="3" | The 15th American Music style="text-align:center"|"So Emotional" | Best Single, R&B;/Dance | |- | style="text-align:center"|"I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)" | Best Music Video | |- | The 10th American Black Achievement Awards | style="text-align:center"|Whitney Houston (herself) | The Music Award | |- | BRAVO magazine's Bravo Otto[E] | style="text- align:center"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Beste Sängerin (Best Female Singer) ― Silver Otto Award | |- | Rennbahn Express magazine's starwahl | style="text- align:center" |Whitney Houston (herself) | Goldener Pinguin Award ― Best Female Singer | |- |1988 Billboard The Year in Music & Video[A] (Year-End Charts: Number One Awards) | style="text-align:center" rowspan="1"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Top Pop Singles Artist ― Female | |} Note: *C^ Houston earned the award for her many humanitarian acts such as a public service announcement, "Say Yes To A Yooungster's Future," urging Black and other minority youth to study the sciences and math, and participation on an Arista Records artists album, The Door to Their Dreams/Arista's 1988 Black Music Month Collection, its proceeds went to the United Negro College Fund to help Black students. *D^ She received the honorary doctorate degree for her contribution to the arts through music. *E^ BRAVO is the largest teen magazine within the German-language sphere. Since 1957, the magazine has distributed its "Bravo Otto" awards based on the readers' vote in different categories each year. == 1989 == {| class="wikitable" ! width=25% | Awards show ! width=25% | Nomination(s) ! width=45% | Categories ! width=5% | Result(s) |- |rowspan="2"|The 16th American Music Awards | style="text-align:center" rowspan="2"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Favorite Pop/Rock Female Artist | |- | Favorite Soul/R&B; Female Artist | |- | The 31st Grammy Awards | style="text- align:center"|"One Moment in Time" | Best Pop Vocal Performance, Female | |- | The 15th People's Choice Awards | style="text-align:center"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Favorite Female Musical Performer | |- | The 3rd Soul Train Music Awards | style="text-align:center"|"Where Do Broken Hearts Go" | Best R&B;/Urban Contemporary Single, Female | |- | The 2nd Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards | style="text-align:center" | Whitney Houston (herself) | Favorite Female Singer | |} == 1990 == {| class="wikitable" ! width=25% | Awards show ! width=25% | Nomination(s) ! width=45% | Categories ! width=5% | Result(s) |- | The 32nd Grammy Awards | style="text-align:center" | "It Isn't, It Wasn't, It Ain't Never Gonna Be" (Duet with Aretha Franklin) | Best R&B; Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocal | |- | The 46th United Negro College Fund Awards[F] | style="text- align:center"|Whitney Houston (herself) | The Frederick D. Patterson Award | |- |The Points of Light Institute (George Bush)[G] | style="text- align:center"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Appointed by George Bush as the first Points of Light Contributing Leader | |- | The 21st Songwriters Hall of Fame Induction & Awards[H] | style="text-align:center"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Howie Richmond Hitmaker Award | |- | The 4th Essence Awards | align ="center" |Whitney Houston (herself) | The Essence Award for the Performing Arts | |} Note: *F^ Houston was honored for her long-standing dedication to Black higher education. *G^ It was a role in which she assisted the President (George H. W. Bush) in calling all Americans to become active in community problem-solving, as well as recognized exemplary public service projects and challenged other artists to advance the Points of Light community service movement. *H^ This award is specifically tailored for artists or "star makers" in the music industry who have been responsible for a substantial number of hit songs for an extended period of time, and who recognize the importance of songs and their writers. == 1991 == {|class="wikitable" ! width=25% | Awards show or organization ! width=25% | Nomination(s) ! width=45% |Categories ! width=5% | Result(s) |- | The 8th American Cinema Awards | style="text-align:center"|Whitney Houston (herself) | The Musical Performer of the Year | |- | The 33rd Grammy Awards | style="text- align:center"|"I'm Your Baby Tonight" | Best Pop Vocal Performance, Female | |- | 1991 BRIT Awards | style="text-align:center"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Best International Female Artist | |- | The 13th American Black Achievement Awards[I] | style="text-align:center"|Whitney Houston (herself) | The Music Award | |- | rowspan="8"|The 2nd Billboard Music Awards | style="text- align:center" rowspan="4"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Top Album Artists ― Female | |- | Top Pop Singles Artist | |- | Top Pop Singles Artist ― Female | |- | Top R&B; Artist | |- | style="text-align:center"|I'm Your Baby Tonight | Top R&B; Album | |- | style="text-align:center" rowspan="2"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Top R&B; Album Artist | |- | Top R&B; Singles Artist | |- | style="text-align:center"|"All the Man That I Need" | Top Adult Contemporary Single | |- |} Note: *I^ Houston was presented this award for her achievements as an award-winning recording, performing and video artist, for her successful I'm Your Baby Tonight World Tour, for her best-selling video and single of "The Star-Spangled Banner" performed at Super Bowl XXV and for her multi platinum album, I'm Your Baby Tonight. == 1992 == {| class="wikitable" ! width=25% | Awards show ! width=25% | Nomination(s) ! width=45% | Categories ! width=5% | Result(s) |- | rowspan="2" | The 26th NAACP Image Awards | style="text-align:center" | HBO Presents Welcome Home Heroes with Whitney Houston | Outstanding Variety Series or Special | |- | style="text- align:center"|"I'm Your Baby Tonight" | Outstanding Female Artist | |- | rowspan="2"|The 13th CableACE Awards | style="text-align:center" rowspan="2"| HBO Presents Welcome Home Heroes with Whitney Houston | Performance in a Music Special or Series | |- | Music Special | |- | rowspan="5"|The 19th American Music Awards | style="text-align:center" rowspan="2"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Favorite Pop/Rock Female Artist | |- | Favorite Soul/R&B; Female Artist | |- | style="text-align:center"|I'm Your Baby Tonight | Favorite Soul/R&B; Album | |- | style="text-align:center"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Favorite Adult Contemporary Artist | |- | style="text-align:center"|I'm Your Baby Tonight | Favorite Adult Contemporary Album | |- | The 34th Grammy Awards | style="text- align:center"|"All the Man That I Need" | Best Pop Vocal Performance, Female | |- | rowspan="2"|The 6th Soul Train Music Awards | style="text- align:center"|I'm Your Baby Tonight | Best R&B;/Soul Album, Female | |- | style="text-align:center"|"All the Man That I Need" | Best R&B;/Soul Single, Female | |- | The 8th Carousel of Hope Ball (The Children's Diabetes Foundation) | style="text-align:center"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Brass Ring Award | |} == 1993 == * Houston received 14 Billboard wins for the year, at the 4th annual Billboard Music Awards Houston won a record-breaking at the time 11 awards for the night(special merit award do not count as nominations or wins in an active category). {| class="wikitable" ! width=25% | Awards show ! width=25% | Nomination(s) ! width=45% | Categories ! width=5% | Result(s) |- |The 35th Grammy Awards | style="text-align:center"|"I Belong to You" | Best R&B; Vocal Performance, Female | |- | The 7th Soul Train Music Awards | style="text-align:center"|"I Will Always Love You" | Best R&B;/Soul Single, Female | |- | rowspan="3"|The 19th People's Choice Awards | style="text-align:center"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Favorite Female Musical Performer | |- | style="text- align:center"|"I Will Always Love You" | Favorite New Music Video | |- | style="text-align:center"|The Bodyguard | Favorite Actress in a Dramatic Motion Picture | |- | rowspan="3"|13th Golden Raspberry Awards | style="text- align:center" rowspan="2"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Worst Actress | |- | Worst New Star | |- | style="text-align:center"| "Queen of the Night | Worst Original Song | |- | rowspan="5"|The 2nd MTV Movie Awards |style="text- align:center" rowspan="4"|The Bodyguard | Best Movie | |- | Best Female Performance | |- | Best Breakthrough Performance | |- | Best On-Screen Duo (with Kevin Costner) | |- | style="text-align:center"|"I Will Always Love You" | Best Song From A Movie | |- | rowspan="15"|The 5th Billboard Music Awards[J] | style="text-align:center"|Whitney Houston (herself) | ★Hot 100 Singles Artist | |- | style="text-align:center"|"I Will Always Love You" | ★Hot 100 Single | |- | style="text-align:center"|Whitney Houston (herself) | ★Hot R&B; Singles Sales | |- | Smash Hits Poll Winners Party | style="text- align:center"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Best Female Artist | |- | align="left" rowspan="2"|BRAVO Magazine's Bravo Otto |style="text- align:center"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Best Actress - Silver Otto Award | |- | style="text-align:center"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Best Female Singer - Silver Otto Award | |- | rowspan="3"|The 7th Japan Gold Disc Awards | style="text-align:center" rowspan="2"|The Bodyguard Soundtrack | グランプリ・アルバム賞 (Album of the Year, International) | |- | アルバム賞 ― 企画 (Compilation Album of the Year, International) | |- | style="text-align:center"|"I Will Always Love You" | グランプリ・シングル賞 (Single of the Year, International) | |- |} Note: *J^ ★ mark means the awards that Houston was presented on the show, other three awards without ★ mark are her extra #1-ranked-categories on Billboard magazine's Year-End Charts of 1993. ==1994== * At the 21st American Music Awards, Houston set a record becoming the first female artist with the most wins in one night, with a total of 7 awards. This ties her with Michael Jackson as they both won 7 awards and one special merit award (in the same night). At the 6th annual World Music Awards, Houston won 5 awards during the ceremony. {| class="wikitable" ! width=25% | Awards show or organization ! width=25% | Nomination(s) ! width=45% | Categories ! Association of Japan (RIAJ) to the product which released before that year, sales over one million units or higher than a product get the award on the same category in that year. == 1995 == Houston won 11 awards at the 4th annual 1993 ceremony, winning top Albums, Singles and Soundtrack categories. In March 2012, she set two Billboard records, becoming the first female with three albums to peak within the Top 10 on Billboard 200www.billboard.com-whitney houston becomes first woman with three albums in top ten and first female with nine albums in the Top 100 on Billboard 200 chart.Whitney Houston Albums and Singles Chart History|BillboardWhitney Houston Albums Chart History|Billboard Houston received the Honoree Billboard Millennium Award at the 2012 Billboard Music Awards ceremony.Whitney Houston Receiving the Billboard Millennium Award According to the official Billboard Music Awards website, Houston has won 16 awards. {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !Nominated work !Categories !Result |- |rowspan="8"|1991 | style="text- align:center" rowspan="4"|Whitney Houston (herself) | Top Album Artists ― Female | |- | Top Pop Singles Artist | |- | Top Pop Singles Artist ― Female | |- | Top R&B; She earned her first Grammy, "Best Pop Vocal Performance, Female", at its 28th annual ceremony of 1986. In 1994, Houston was honored with "Album of the Year" and "Record of the Year" for The Bodyguard Original Soundtrack Album and "I Will Always Love You", respectively. At the 39th ceremony, she was nominated for "Best Song Written for a Motion Picture, Television or Other Visual Media" for "Count on Me", which was her first and only Grammy nomination as a songwriter. In 2000, Houston became the recipient of "Best Female R&B; Vocal Performance" award after being nominated for the category seven times since her debut. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Categories ! Houston held the record for the most AMA wins by a female artist until 2018 when she was surpassed by Taylor Swift; and along with Michael Jackson, they hold the record for the most AMAs ever won in a single year with 8 awards. The following is a list of American Music Awards wins and nominations she has achieved since her debut. {| class="wikitable" |- !
